title: 113_s2701
content: The Act titled "Stopping Illegal Obamacare Subsidies Act" limits auto-enrollment in health plans under American Health Benefit Exchanges until inconsistencies outlined in a June 2014 report are resolved by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must make public the steps to resolve inconsistencies in eligibility systems for healthcare programs within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, methods to monitor progress in resolving inconsistencies must be disclosed within the same timeframe. Premium assistance tax credits and reduced cost-sharing programs may be suspended if inconsistencies are not resolved. Suspension of premium assistance tax credits and cost-sharing programs for plan year 2015 until all inconsistencies related to invalid social security numbers are resolved. Requests for additional information from individuals with inconsistent applicant information on State or Federal Exchanges, with a 90-day window to provide the required information. During an inconsistency period, individuals seeking enrollment in a qualified health plan on a State or Federal Exchange may be enrolled but cannot access premium assistance credits or reduced cost-sharing programs. If additional information is not provided upon request, benefits may be suspended. During an inconsistency period, if an applicant fails to submit requested additional information, they will be withdrawn from premium assistance credit and reduced cost-sharing programs. The applicant must re-enroll with accurate information during the next open enrollment period. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "inconsistencies" refer to differences in self-attested information provided by an applicant for health plan enrollment and data received from data sources, impacting eligibility for financial assistance programs under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The "inconsistency period" is defined as 90 days. The term "inconsistency period" refers to the 90-day period following the notice of an inconsistency sent to the applicant for financial assistance programs under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
